dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: So, Melanie Joly, Canada's Foreign Minister, actually recommended removing Oleg Boyko from the sanctions list.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, Melanie Joly, Canada's Foreign Minister, actually recommended removing Oleg Boyko from the sanctions list.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Canada's Foreign Minister, Mlanie Joly, advised her government to remove businessman Oleg Boyko from the list of individuals previously sanctioned in connection with Russia's invasion of Ukraine.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that's a pretty significant reversal. He was originally added back in May 2022.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that's a pretty significant reversal. He was originally added back in May twenty twenty two.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Mr. Boyko was added to Canada's sanctions list in April 2022.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and his legal team argued he had no business ties in Canada and wasn't involved in Russian politics at all.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and his legal team argued he had no business ties in Canada and wasn't involved in Russian politics at all.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The applicant's lawyers insisted that Mr. Boyko has no business in Canada, and he is not associated with the authorities and state bodies of Russia, and does not participate in Russia's political decision-making.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Which, uh, seems to have been persuasive—the Supreme Court case definitely put pressure on the ministry to review it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Which, uh, seems to have been persuasive-the Supreme Court case definitely put pressure on the ministry to review it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In August 2023, Oleg Boyko filed a lawsuit against the Canadian Foreign Ministry in the Federal Court of Canada.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And the official notice came through on November 8th, right? The letter to Boyko confirming the lift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the official notice came through on November eighth, right? The letter to Boyko confirming the lift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In the end, Canada's Foreign Minister, Mlanie Joly, authorized to consider matters of imposing and lifting sanctions in accordance with national legislation, reviewed the appeal and decided to grant it, notifying the applicant in a letter dated November 10, 2023.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. Then by November 16th, it was publicly confirmed on the government website—section 731 repealed, specifically naming him.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. Then by November sixteenth, it was publicly confirmed on the government website-section seven hundred thirty one repealed, specifically naming him.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: On November 15, a statement was published on the Canadian government's website indicating that Item 731 of Part 1 of Schedule 1 to the Special Economic Measures (Russia) Regulations is repealed.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: His lawyer seemed pretty pleased, calling it a balanced and fair move for business figures not tied to politics.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: His lawyer seemed pretty pleased, calling it a balanced and fair move for business figures not tied to politics.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: We are pleased that sanctions against businessmen unrelated to politics are gradually being lifted, reflecting a balanced and fair stance of countries toward business, commented Mr. Boyko's lawyer on the decision of the Canadian authorities.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: It's interesting though—Boyko's Finstar Financial Group operates in 25 countries. That's a huge footprint.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It's interesting though-Boyko's Finstar Financial Group operates in twenty five countries. That's a huge footprint.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oleg Boyko is the founder and chairman of the supervisory board of Finstar Financial Group, engaged in investment activities in 25 countries worldwide in the fields of financial services, IT, real estate, retail, and the entertainment industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, investments in finance, IT, real estate… pretty diverse portfolio.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, investments in finance, I T, real estate... pretty diverse portfolio.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Oleg Boyko is the founder and chairman of the supervisory board of Finstar Financial Group, engaged in investment activities in 25 countries worldwide in the fields of financial services, IT, real estate, retail, and the entertainment industry.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And now they're apparently working on getting sanctions lifted in New Zealand too.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And now they're apparently working on getting sanctions lifted in New Zealand too.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to Mr. Boyko's lawyer, work is currently underway to lift sanctions in Australia.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder how many other cases like this are out there—businesspeople caught in broad sanctions.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder how many other cases like this are out there-businesspeople caught in broad sanctions.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure. It raises questions about how these lists are compiled and reviewed in the first place.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure. It raises questions about how these lists are compiled and reviewed in the first place.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. Due process matters, even during something as charged as sanction regimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. Due process matters, even during something as charged as sanction regimes.

artist_script:
HostA: So, Melanie Joly, Canada's Foreign Minister, actually recommended removing Oleg Boyko from the sanctions list.
HostB: Yeah, that’s a pretty significant reversal. He was originally added back in May 2022.
HostA: Right, and his legal team argued he had no business ties in Canada and wasn’t involved in Russian politics at all.
HostB: Which, uh, seems to have been persuasive—the Supreme Court case definitely put pressure on the ministry to review it.
HostA: And the official notice came through on November 8th, right? The letter to Boyko confirming the lift.
HostB: Exactly. Then by November 16th, it was publicly confirmed on the government website—section 731 repealed, specifically naming him.
HostA: His lawyer seemed pretty pleased, calling it a balanced and fair move for business figures not tied to politics.
HostB: It’s interesting though—Boyko’s Finstar Financial Group operates in 25 countries. That’s a huge footprint.
HostA: Yeah, investments in finance, IT, real estate… pretty diverse portfolio.
HostB: And now they’re apparently working on getting sanctions lifted in New Zealand too.
HostA: Makes you wonder how many other cases like this are out there—businesspeople caught in broad sanctions.
HostB: For sure. It raises questions about how these lists are compiled and reviewed in the first place.
HostA: Absolutely. Due process matters, even during something as charged as sanction regimes.
